docs.lead_paragraph: ''Is Our Food Safe?'' by Warren Leon and Caroline Smith DeWaal. Three Rivers Press, $14.95. ''Many dishes, many diseases,'' cautions a Latin proverb, which, in another translation, is more specific: ''Much meat, much malady.''
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book Is Our Food Safe? by Warren Leon and Caroline Smith DeWaal; photo (M)
docs.snippet: ''Is Our Food Safe?'' by Warren Leon and Caroline Smith DeWaal. Three Rivers Press, $14.95.    ''Many dishes, many diseases,'' cautions a Latin proverb, which, in another translation, is more specific: ''Much meat, much malady.''

docs.lead_paragraph: People with exceptional memories have ordinary brains but use them in a way that brings more of the mind's powers to bear, according to a study that examined whether damaged memories could be bolstered by teaching similar techniques. In the study, which was published online last week in Nature Neuroscience, researchers from University College London put competitors from the World Memory Championships and eight comparison subjects through three tests while using a brain scanning technique to track the activation of different parts of the brain.
docs.abstract: Study conducted by University College London researchers, published online in Nature Neuroscience, finds that people with exceptional memory have ordinary brains but use them in different ways; drawing (M)
